summary: This is an email from Janis organizing materials and assignments for a mock bail argument exercise at the NYU Prosecution Clinic, scheduled for October 14, 2020. It references case materials from US v. Epstein, US v. Maxwell, and US v. Ng, and outlines team assignments for students to role-play as government and defense attorneys.

persons.name: Janis
persons.context: Sender of the email organizing the mock bail argument exercise, assigning teams and materials for the NYU Prosecution Clinic.

persons.name: Judge Moses
persons.context: Named as the judge before whom the mock bail arguments will be presented during the exercise.

events.title: Mock Bail Arguments
events.description: Scheduled mock bail argument exercise for the NYU Prosecution Clinic, where student teams role-play as government and defense attorneys using materials from real cases.

events.title: Mock Sentencing
events.description: Follow-up exercise where students who did not argue during the mock bail arguments will participate in a mock sentencing.

keyFacts: The document is an instructional email for a law school clinic mock bail argument exercise using real case materials.
Referenced case materials include documents from US v. Epstein, US v. Maxwell, and US v. Ng, indicating these cases are used as teaching examples.
The exercise involves student teams role-playing as government and defense attorneys, simulating real legal proceedings.
The email organizer is named Janis, who coordinates team assignments and material distribution for the NYU Prosecution Clinic.
